awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Physics Research at Brigham Young University
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the renewal of the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) and Research Experience for Teachers (RET) site in physics at Brigham Young University. The program will develop students' abilities in physics research by hands-on experiences. Direct mentoring and group training will help the students acquire the skills needed to get started in research. Group training will include instruction in experimental and computational techniques, preparation for graduate school, and scientific writing and presentations. Students will also benefit from close mentoring by faculty. This contact will give them role models for professional ethics and standards and opportunities to discuss many aspects of graduate school opportunities and careers in physics and related fields. The RET component will impact the experience of secondary teachers who participate in the program but also the students they teach. RET participants will be encouraged to look for ways to incorporate their summer experiences in their classroom. 

Participating students and teachers will participate in a ten-week summer physics research program in computational plasma physics, ultrafast nonlinear optics, experimental and computational condensed matter physics, x-ray and XUV sources and optics, microfabrication technology, visible astronomy, or materials science. Participants will experience the joy of research by being involved in a research project from proposal presentation through performing the research and reporting results.  The award is funded by both the Division of Physics and the Division of Astronomical Sciences within the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the duration of the award, a total of fifty-seven undergraduates and nine High school teachers from all over the USA participated in an intense ten-week summer research experience in the Department of Physics and Astronomy at Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah. All participants engaged in cutting-edge research under the guidance of a faculty mentor and in collaboration with their local research group on a project of mutual interest. The topics covered a very wide range of physics areas, from underwater acoustics and exoplanet astronomy to nanomagnetism and numerical relativity and including complex modeling, quantum information and superconductivity to name a few.

Projects involved conceptual discussions and theoretical calculations on the blackboard and computational facilities, hands-on laboratory work on campus as well as brief field trips locally and to national laboratories.

The program also included professional development activities such as workshops in communication skills, science ethics, belonging and diversity, career advice and preparation for graduate school.

All participants gave short weekly reports as well as several professional scientific presentations to their peers and mentors and everyone turned in a final report at the end of the ten weeks.

Several participants presented their research results at regional and national scientific meetings after the completion of the summer program. The research also led to many student-authored publications in professional journals.

The participants came from very diverse backgrounds but formed closed-knit groups thanks to a common interest in science as well as sharing housing and partaking in many social activities for the duration of the program. The outdoors activities included hiking the slot canyons of Southern Utah and visiting state and national parks in red rock country. Cultural activities included attending plays, visiting museums and cultural sites in Utah. Game nights, talent shows, BBQs, all activities involving soem level of mentor participation.

This intense research experience of confronting difficult problems, spending long hours in the lab solving tricky problems and adjusting equipment or discussing the laws that describe the universe allowed all students to gauge their motivation for advanced studies and research in science.

For the participants, many of whom attended smaller colleges with limited research experience, the exposure to research through the REU program at Brigham Young University was a first but critical experience in shaping their professional trajectory. Many of the participants are now graduate students in schools across the country, well on their way to become professional scientists and science educators. Others have joined the work force as STEM professionals. many are still in touch with their former REU mentors. Our alumni are one ofour most effective recruiting agents for future editions of the summer porgram.

For the high school teacher, the research experience was a unique opportunity to rekindle their interest and fluency in science and research. They were able to take all what they discovered and experienced at BYU back to their home institution and share it with their students. In doing so they help prepare future generations in science, technology, engineering and mathematics.
